title: 107_hr1621
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001". The Arabia Mountain area contains natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources that represent the heritage of the United States. Managing these resources through partnerships between public and private entities is the best approach. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in DeKalb County, Georgia is a 535-acre park. The Arabia Mountain area's preservation involves partnerships between public and private entities to combine resources and engage communities. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in DeKalb County, Georgia protects granite outcrop ecosystems, wetlands, and federally-protected plant species. Panola Mountain, a national natural landmark, is located in the 860-acre Panola Mountain State Conservation Park and showcases a pristine granite outcrop. Panola Mountain in Panola Mountain State Conservation Park is a rare granite outcrop. Miners Creek Preserve shows early human activity. Lithonia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain exhibit the history of granite mining. Klondike may become a National Historic District. The history of granite mining in Georgia and its impact on the United States. Klondike eligible for National Historic District designation. Lithonia has 2 structures on National Register of Historic Places. Purposes of the Act include recognizing, preserving, and promoting natural and cultural resources in the area. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, promote, interpret, and make available natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources in the area including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other significant sites. It also aims to assist Georgia and the counties of DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry in developing and implementing a cultural, historical, and land resource management program to protect, enhance, and interpret the significant resources within the heritage area. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Heritage area - Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area established by section 4.
(2) Management entity - Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance or successor.
(3) Management plan - plan for the heritage area developed under section 6.
(4) Secretary - Secretary of the Interior.
(5) State - State of Georgia. SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. Established the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in the State, consisting of certain parcels of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. The boundaries are depicted on a map available for public inspection. The Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance is designated as the management entity. SEC. 5. AUTHORITIES AND DUTIES OF THE MANAGEMENT ENTITY. The management entity has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts for goods and services. They are also responsible for developing and submitting the management plan to the Secretary. The management entity is required to develop and submit a management plan to the Secretary, considering the interests of various groups within the heritage area. Priority is given to implementing actions outlined in the plan, including assisting government and nonprofit entities. The management entity must prioritize actions from the management plan, such as assisting government and nonprofit organizations in preserving resources and encouraging local governments to adopt land use policies. Public meetings on plan implementation are required quarterly. The management entity must conduct quarterly public meetings on the implementation of the management plan and submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income. The entity is also required to make all financial records available for audit by the Secretary. The management entity must provide all financial records for audit by the Secretary, including those of receiving organizations spending Federal funds. The management entity must provide all financial records for audit by the Secretary, including those of receiving organizations spending Federal funds. Federal funds under this Act cannot be used to acquire real property, but other Federal funds can be used for authorized purposes. The management entity must provide financial records for audit by the Secretary, including those of receiving organizations spending Federal funds. Federal funds under this Act cannot be used to acquire real property. The management entity must develop a management plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept in the feasibility study. The plan should consider State and local plans and involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations in the area. The management plan for the heritage area must consider State and local plans, involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations, and include an inventory of resources that should be preserved, restored, managed, or maintained. The management plan for the heritage area includes an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation. The management plan for the heritage area includes an interpretation plan, a program for implementation, actions by various entities to protect resources, funding sources, and evaluation of the management entity. The management plan for the heritage area includes partnerships to protect resources, identification of funding sources, and evaluation of the management entity. The plan must be submitted to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of enactment. The management entity must submit the management plan for the heritage area to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of enactment. Failure to submit the plan will result in a halt of additional funding until the plan is submitted. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days of receiving it. The management entity must submit the heritage area's management plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of enactment. The Secretary, in consultation with the State, must approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days of receiving it. If the plan is disapproved, the Secretary must provide written reasons for the disapproval. The Secretary must advise the management entity in writing of reasons for disapproval, make recommendations for revisions, and allow the entity to submit revised management plans within 90 days. After the Secretary approves a management plan, the management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the plan for approval within 90 days. The management entity must review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the management plan to the Secretary for approval before implementing them with funds from this Act. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to heritage areas for developing and implementing management plans, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. Authorization of $10,000,000 for the Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. Federal share capped at 50%. Secretary's grant authority ends on September 30, 2016.
